final_answer.precision_note: I and t are 3 s.f. and Cu Ar is 4–5 s.f.; report deposited mass to 3 s.f.

method: Convert time to seconds: 30.0 min = 30.0 × 60 = 1800 s. Total charge passed is I×t = 1.50 × 1800 = 2700 C. Convert charge to moles of electrons using the Faraday constant: n(e−) = 2700/96500 = 0.02798 mol e−. From the cathode half-equation Cu2+ + 2e− → Cu, 2 mol e− deposit 1 mol Cu, so n(Cu) = 0.02798/2 = 0.01399 mol. Mass deposited = n × Ar(Cu) = 0.01399 × 63.55 = 0.8887 g ≈ 0.889 g.
checks: Order-of-magnitude check: 1.50 A for 1800 s gives 2700 C; dividing by ~10^5 gives ~0.03 mol e−, so ~0.015 mol Cu, which is ~1 g — consistent with 0.889 g.
If the time or current doubled, mass would double; the linear dependence on I and t matches electrolysis expectations.
